questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be:

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Hence, erythropoietin levels (EPO) are estimated next, to differentiate between primary or secondary polycythemia. Based on EPO levels:

  • Primary polycythemia - normal/ decreased
  • Secondary polycythemia - increased

Options A and B: JAK 2 mutation and Philadelphia chromosome analysis is only done as a last resort.

Option D: Bone marrow estimation with reticulin is done for myelofibrosis which can be seen in the spent/ late stage of the disease. However, peripheral smear findings are not suggestive of primary myelofibrosis. Leukoerythroblastic reaction with dacrocytes is seen in myelofibrosis.

Related Pearl: Comparison between Properties of Various Types of Polycythemia

  Plasma volume RBC Mass O2 saturation EPO concentration

Relative

polycythemia

     ↓ N N N

Polycythemia

vera

     ↑ ↑ N   ↓

EPO- producing tumors

 N ↑ N ↑

Hypoxia

(High altitude)

 N ↑   ↓ ↑

EPO: Erythropoietin

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with skin-colored umbilicated papules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
The given microscopic image shows large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is about 300 nm in size, the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans

Tzanck smear shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30–35 μm).

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules (shown below). A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Tubulin is a part of microtubules and is not an intermediate filament.

There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.

1. Actin microfilaments:

These fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin) noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

2. Intermediate filaments:

These rope-like intermediate filament fibers are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not possess the quality of active reorganization like actin and microtubules. They are responsible for cellular tensile strength, which allows the cells to bear mechanical stress.

Type of intermediate filament Description
Lamin A, B, and C These proteins are localized in the nuclear lamina of all cells. Mutations in lamin proteins are associated with certain disorders such as familial partial lipodystrophy type 2, Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome, and familial dilated cardiomyopathy.
Vimentin These are mainly found in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts, endothelium).
Desmin Present in sarcomeres in muscle cells.
Neurofilament These are found in neuronal axons, imparting strength and rigidity.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein Present in glial cells around neurons.
Cytokeratins

These proteins are the most diverse among IFs and constitute type I (acidic) and type II (basic) IF proteins.

There are at least 30 isoforms of this protein divided into two groups: Epithelial keratins (found in epithelial cells) and trichocytic keratins (found in hair-keratin).

3. Microtubules:

These are formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin, and beta-tubulin. The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

Related Pearl: Cytoskeleton

Cytoskeleton

Microfilaments

Intermediate Filaments

Microtubules

Diameter

5-9 nm

8-14 nm

25 nm

Examples

Filamentous (F) actin

Globular (G) actin

Keratin, vimentin, desmin, glial fibrillary acid protein, peripherin, neurofilaments, lamins

Dynamin, Dynein, Kinesin,tubulin

Functions

Play a vital role in various cellular contractile systems,

including muscle contraction and amoeboid movement (lamellopodia)

serve as mechanical stiffeners for microvilli

Help resist mechanical stress

Lamins connect nuclear membrane to cell membrane

Keratin prevents blistering of the skin

Vimentin forms a flexible scaffolding for the cell and help it resist external pressure

Maintain asymmetric cell shapes and coordinate complex cell movements

specifically serving as tracks for transport of secretory vesicles within a cell using molecular motors

serving as the main structural and functional component of cilia and flagella

forming a mitotic spindle during cell division

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
questions.solution:
The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as faggot cells (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).  

Since the question specifically asks about the cell, the best answer is faggot cell (not Auer rods).

Option A: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia).  

Option B: The term flaming promyelocyte refers to cells that appear to be breaking apart, taking on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding cellular matrix. 

Option C: Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear dusky or hazy and are referred to as dusky promyelocytes.

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution:
Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system.

Causes of prolonged PT:

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists
  • Liver disease - obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare)

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway.

Causes of prolonged APTT:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants
  • A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII
  • Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs
  • Vitamin K deficiency

Related Pearl: Coagulation Pathways and its Abnormalities

Test results Inherited causes Acquired causes

Prolonged PT 

Evaluates extrinsic pathway factors

Normal PT: 11-13 seconds

 Factor VII deficiency 

Mild vitamin K deficiency

Liver disease

Warfarin

Prolonged aPTT

Evaluates intrinsic pathway factors

Normal aPTT: 25-35 seconds

Factors VIII, IX, XI deficiency

Factor XII, prekallikrein, or HMW kininogen deficiency

von Willebrand disease

 Heparin, lupus anticoagulant, acquired von Willebrand disease

Prolonged PT + prolonged aPTT

Evaluates common pathway factors

Prothrombin (II), fibrinogen (I), factors V and factor X deficiencies

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Severe liver disease

Severe vitamin K deficiency

Direct thrombin inhibitor-argatroban, dabigatran

Direct factor Xa inhibitor-rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban

Fondaparinux

questions.text: A 58-year-old man died 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. On autopsy, an atheromatous plaque was seen obstructing the left anterior descending artery. Which type of calcification is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Atheromatous plaques are associated with dystrophic calcification. This is seen in the presence of normal calcium levels in the serum.

The deposition of calcium in dead or dying tissues is called dystrophic calcification. Although it occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium, it can be worsened by hypercalcemia.

Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type. Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Types of calcifications

  Dystrophic calcification Metastatic calcification
Location Dead and dying tissues Normal interstitial tissues of the vasculature, kidneys, lungs, and gastric mucosa.
Calcium metabolism Normal deranged causing hypercalcemia
Examples

Calcific valvular stenosis

Advanced Atheromatous plaque

Monckeberg medial sclerosis

Parathyroid tumors

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Paget disease

vitamin D intoxication

Sarcoidosis

Renal failure

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to ________
questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin.

Hepcidin is released by the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels. It inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, iron becomes trapped within duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost as these cells are sloughed.

Note: In hereditary hemochromatosis, there will be impaired hepcidin synthesis resulting in increased iron absorption.

questions.text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis and his Hb was 5.2gm/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals were BP - 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate - 110/min. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). 

TACO is caused by rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products. This condition is characterized by:

  • Dyspnea with O2% <90 at room air
  • Bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray
  • Systolic hypertension
  • Elevation of brain natriuretic peptide, 1.5 times that of pre-transfusion levels

It can be prevented by administering the transfusion slowly, at the rate of 1 to 2 ml of blood/kg of body weight per hour. Diuretics are also used if necessary.

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such reactions can be prevented by using leukoreduced RBCs.
Removal of leukocytes from the blood is called leukoreduction. It is done before storage to prevent cytokine formation.
FNHTR may occur due to the following:
  • Sensitization to the WBC antigens by previous blood transfusions or pregnancy
  • Cytokines produced by the donor leukocytes during storage
  • Bacterial contamination

Note: Luspatercept is an erythroid maturation agent, a receptor fusion protein consisting of a modified extracellular domain of human activin receptor type-2B linked to the human Ig-G1 Fc domain. The drug was recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of transfusion-dependent thalassemia.

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

CXR: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: If DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, which gene causes cell cycle arrest?
questions.solution:
If the DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, the p53 gene causes arrest of the cell cycle in G1 phase to provide time for DNA repair. In case the DNA damage could not be repaired, p53 triggers apoptosis.
 
In conditions where there is mutation in p53 gene, the cells with damaged DNA continue to replicate and thus may undergo neoplastic transformation.

Related Pearl: Tumor suppressor genes

Chromosome

TGF- Beta Receptor

E-cadherin

Growth inhibition 

Cell adhesion

Chromosome 19

NF2 Cytoskeletal instability Chromosome 22

APC/Beta-catenin

 Inhibition of signal transduction Chromosome 5

SMAD2 and SMAD4 TGF- beta signal transduction Chromosome 18

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hemostatic agent?
questions.solution:
Boric acid is not a hemostatic agent. 
 
Topical hemostatic agents used in practice include:
  • Hemostatic field dressings
  • Surgical hemostatic agents

1. The hemostatic field dressings are the granular and gauze-based agents which are used to facilitate coagulation and hemostasis. The active ingredients used in various hemostatic field dressings are kaolin, mineral zeolite, and chitosan.

 
Mechanism of action
Advantage
Disadvantage
Kaolin
Cation based activation of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade
It is non-granular compound. Hence, it does not leave any residue upon removal of the dressing
Clots may be disrupted upon removal. It is less effective in functional or dilutional coagulopathies.
Mineral zeolite
Adsorbs the water, thereby increasing the concentration of the clotting factors, platelets, RBCs.
It is available in two forms:
 
Granular zeolite is effective for pouring into low-flow wounds.
 
The mesh-embedded product is useful in high flow wounds.
The chemical reaction which causes adsorption of water is an exothermic reaction. This causes local tissue damage. The granules may be difficult to be removed.
Chetosan
Poly-N-acetylglucosamine is commonly known as chitin. The deacetylated form of chitin is called chitosan. It has mucoadhesive properties which causes the dressing to adhere to the tissues. It induces vasospasm and attracts RBCs and platelets to the site of bleeding.
It has antimicrobial properties. It can be easily applied and has a long shelf-life.
As the dressing material adheres to the tissues, it may cause disruption of the clots upon removal.

 

2. The surgical hemostatic agents are further divided into the following groups based on the nature of the agent:

 
  • Caustic agents: They act by causing local tissue destruction, which leads to protein coagulation and precipitation. This further leads to thrombus formation and sealing of the small blood vessels. The agents include Monsel solution (a20% ferric nitrate solution), silver nitrate, and aluminum chloride.
 
  • Biological physical agents: They act by promoting platelet activation and formation of three-dimensional matrix for the formation of clots. These agents are used in several operations including neurosurgical, orthopedic, thoracic, abdominal, and vascular procedures. The agents include gelatin, oxidized cellulose, and microfibrillar collagen.
 
  • Physiologic agents: These agents activate a specific step of the coagulation cascade and promotes the clot formation. These agents include thrombin and fibrin glue/sealant.
 
  • Combination or polymer agents: These agents include several different combinations of the above agents and various synthetic hemostatic agents. Examples include gelatin-thrombin agent, polyethylene glycol hydrogel, and glutaraldehyde cross-linked albumin.

questions.text: Acute inflammatory response is not seen in:
questions.solution:
An inflammatory response is not seen in apoptosis. In this process, the cell membrane remains intact. Hence, there is no leakage of cell contents and no surrounding inflammation.
 
On the other hand, other forms of cell death including necrosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis involve the disintegration of the cell membrane. This causes the cell contents to leak out of the cell leading to an acute inflammatory response.

Related Pearl: Necrosis vs Apoptosis

Feature

Necrosis

Apoptosis

Mechanism

Enzymatic or ischemic process

Passive process

Genetically programmed cell death

Active process
Physiologic or pathologic role

Invariably pathologic 

Both physiologic and pathologic

Cell size

Enlarged (swelling)

Reduced (shrinkage)

Cells affected

Group of cells

Single cell death

Nucleus

Pyknosis →karyorrhexis →karyolysis

Fragmentation into nucleosome-size fragments

Plasma membrane

Disrupted

Intact; altered structure

Cellular contents

Enzymatic digestion; may leak out of cell

Intact; may be released in apoptotic bodies

Inflammation

Present

Absent

Marker

No marker

Annexin V

PAGE (DNA electrophoresis)

Smear pattern

Step-ladder pattern

questions.text: An affected male does not have affected children but an affected female always has affected children. Type of inheritance?
questions.solution:
In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.
 
The mitochondrial inheritance pattern is as shown in the image below:
The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance, as the disease is transmitted through the affected mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria.
 
The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa has very few mitochondria if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.
 
Therefore, affected mother transmits the disease to all the offsprings (both male and female), and only the daughters of the affected mother, will further transmit the disease.
 
Characteristic features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, organs that are most dependent on the oxidative phosphorylation are the ones most affected in diseases due to mutations in mtDNA. These organs include central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys.
  • There are several thousands of copies of mtDNA in each mitochondria, of which only a few copies are affected in case of mutation. Therefore, a diseased individual possesses copies of both wild type mtDNA and mutant mtDNA in each mitochondria  This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy. 
  • The disease manifests if a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA are present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction, called the threshold effect. In most cases, this threshold effect is reached in the organs as mentioned above.
  • Also, during a cell division, the wild and mutant copies of the mtDNA are unequally distributed among the daughter cells. As a result, the expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of liver failure?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of liver failure is paracetamol poisoning.

The most common hepatotoxin causing chronic liver disease is alcohol.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Drug- and Toxin-Induced Hepatic Injury

Pathology/Pattern

Causative agent

Cholestatic pattern

Contraceptive and anabolic steroids,

Spotty hepatocyte necrosis

Methyldopa, phenytoin

Massive necrosis

Acetaminophen, halothane

Chronic hepatitis

Isoniazid

Large and small droplet fat

Ethanol, Methotrexate, Total parenteral nutrition

Microvesicular steatosis

Valproate, tetracycline, aspirin (Reye syndrome), HAART

Steatohepatitis with Mallory-Denk bodies

Ethanol, amiodarone

Fibrosis and cirrhosis

Alcohol, methotrexate, enalapril, vitamin A and other retinoids

Noncaseating epithelioid granulomas

Sulfonamides, amiodarone, isoniazid

Fibrin ring granulomas

Allopurinol

Budd-Chiari syndrome

Oral contraceptives

questions.text: Which is the most important light microscopic feature of irreversible cell injury?

choices.text: Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

questions.solution:
Nuclear changes like pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis are features of irreversible cell injury visible on light microscopy.

The ultrastructural findings visible on electron microscopy include: 

  • Large amorphous floccular densities in mitochondria
  • Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
  • Ribosomal detachment from endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Which of the following are features of iron deficiency anaemia?

choices.text: TIBC increased, Ferritin decreased, Transferrin saturation increased
TIBC increased, Soluble transferrin receptor decreased, Ferritin increased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin increased

questions.solution:
In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor?
questions.solution:
The major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor is endothelial cells.

vWF is also found in:

  • Platelet granules - lesser compared to endothelial cells
  • Endothelial cells within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies
  • Subendothelium - binds to collagen

questions.text: Which of the following causes vasodilation?
questions.solution:
Histamine causes marked dilatation of smaller blood vessels that include arterioles, capillaries, and venules.

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

Histamine Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, endothelial activation
Prostaglandins Vasodilation, pain, fever
Leukotrienes Increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6)

Local: endothelial activation (expression of adhesion molecules).

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)
Chemokines Chemotaxis, leukocyte activation
Platelet-activating factor Vasoconstriction, Vasodilation (at low concentration), increased vascular permeability, leukocyte adhesion, chemotaxis, degranulation, oxidative burst
Complement Leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), vasodilation (mast cell stimulation)
Kinins Increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, vasodilation, pain

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text: Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are seen in:
questions.solution:
Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are both seen in apoptosis.

Apoptosis has two pathways:

Mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway Death receptor or extrinsic pathway
Activation inside the cell  Activation outside the cell 

Occurs in response to:

  • DNA damage
  • Radiation
  • Infection

Involved in:

  • Elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes
  • Killing of target cells by cytotoxic T-cells

Involves release of pro-apoptotic proteins (BAX, BAK)

They form a BAX-BAK channel in the mitochondrial membrane

Involves death receptors on cell surfaces (have a death domain)

These include TNF-1 and Fas (CD95) of the TNF family

Leakage of cytochrome-c results in the formation of Cyt.c-APAF1 complex, followed by apoptosome formation

FasL on T-cells binds to Fas bind adapter proteins via death domain

Activation of caspase 9

Activation of caspases 8 and 10
Both pathways converge into a common pathway that involves the activation of caspases 3, 6, 7 (executioner caspases)

APAF-1 - Apoptosis activating factor-1

TNF - Tumor necrosis factor

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given serum electrophoresis image?
questions.solution:
The given electrophoresis shows hypoalbuminemia and increased alpha-2 globulin, which is classically seen in nephrotic syndrome.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: All are small round blue cell tumors except:
questions.solution:
Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.

Hemangioblastomas are tumors of central nervous system that originate from vascular tissues. They demonstrate the proliferation of capillaries with variable sized, closely packed, and thin walled vessels as seen in the image below.

Small round blue cell tumors consist of small round cells that stain blue on routine H&E staining sections. They include:

  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor
  • Rhabdomyosarcomas
  • Acute leukemia

The following is the image of neuroblastoma showing Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. The flow cytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes 3& 4) is shown below (Boxes 1 & 2 are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens, is unaffected, accounting for the presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome.

The given clinical scenario and the flow cytometry is suggestive of Hyper IgM syndrome. The flow cytometry shows the following findings:

  • In comparison of image 3 to 1, where side scatter is plotted against CD 19: B-cell gating is present. 
    Gating of B cells means selecting a cell during a flow cytometry experiment for further analysis or data presentation.CD 19 is widely expressed on B cells. Hence the graph shows B cell gating. Side scatter measurement provides information about the granularity of a cell.
  • In comparison of image 4 to 2, where CD 40 is plotted against CD 19: B cells are present only in quadrant 4, which means that there is CD 40 deficiency.

The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens is unaffected, accounting for the presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome.

Given below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results:

Interpretation of results:

Quadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen

Quadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens.

Quadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens 

Quadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen

 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in SCID?
questions.solution:
BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia and not SCID (severe combined immunodeficiency).

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. In this condition, the following genes are involved:

  • JAK3
  • RAG1
  • IL-7R

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including: 

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except:
questions.solution:
Anaphylactoid reactions are those reactions that are similar to the anaphylactic reactions but are not IgE mediated. These reactions are caused by direct degranulation of the mast cells or basophils, which causes the release of mediators.

Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

In 2014, World Allergy Organisation has introduced two new terms:

  • Immunologic anaphylaxis - It includes anaphylactic reactions mediated by IgE, IgG (in animals), and immune complex/ complement-mediated reactions.
  • Non-immunologic anaphylaxis (previously called anaphylactoid reaction) - It includes reactions caused by agents which cause massive degranulation of mast cells or basophils in the absence of immunoglobulin.

The image given below shows the sequence of events in type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except:
questions.solution:
Enhancer deletion does not convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.

Mechanisms of activating oncogenes:

Mechanism Activation of oncogenes
Mutation Mutation activates the gene. A classic example is the point mutation of the RAS oncogene.
Promoter insertion  Insertion of a viral promoter region near a gene activates it.
Enhancer insertion  Insertion of a viral enhancer region near a gene activates it.
Chromosomal translocation  One chromosome is split off and joined to another. An example is the Philadelphia chromosome.
Gene amplification   Abnormal multiplication of a gene resulting in many copies. This can occur with oncogenes and genes involved in tumor drug resistance.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to _____
questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin, which is an iron efflux channel in the enterocyte.

Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by the liver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyte to the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells (enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off.

Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors:

  • Increased levels of iron
  • Inflammatory cytokines

Transcription of hepcidin is decreased by the following factors:

  • Iron deficiency
  • Hypoxia
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis

Hepcidin is encoded by the HAMP gene and its mutations are associated with hereditary hemochromatosis.

questions.text: Which of the following about γ𝛿 T-cells is incorrect:

choices.text: Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
Need  antigen processing and presentation for it recognition

questions.solution:
γ𝛿 T-cells do not need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition.

There are two types of T cells: γ𝛿 T-cells and αβ T-cells.

The functions of γ𝛿 T-cells:

  • Provide protection against mycobacteria by direct killing of infected macrophages
  • Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
  • Plays a role in maintaining self-tolerance
  • Capable of recognising and lysing diverse cancers in an MHC-unrestricted manner

αβ T-cells have MHC restricted action.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the procedure done using the instrument given in the image below?

choices.text: Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position
Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease

questions.solution:
The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not in itself a contraindication for bone marrow biopsy. However, a platelet count >20,000 is ensured for safety purposes.

Indications of bone marrow biopsy:

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia
  • Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias
  • Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin, suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections, or granulomatous diseases

Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy:

  • Severe hemophilia
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Severe bleeding disorders

Procedure for bone marrow biopsy:

Prone or lateral position is chosen for the procedure. Posterior superior iliac spine is identified. After disinfection and local anaesthesia, the patient is asked to inhale slowly through the nose and exhale slowly through the mouth to relieve anxiety .The needle is inserted and rotated on its axis.

On reaching the desired depth, the stylet is removed and needle is advanced. The needle is rotated in the opposite direction to loosen the specimen. It is then withdrawn using the same rotational movement.

questions.text: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells. It occurs in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections.

Options B and C: Kartagener syndrome is also known as  primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile cilia syndrome. It occurs due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by the triad of: 

  • Sinusitis
  • Situs inversus
  • Bronchiectasis

Option D: In cystic fibrosis ciliary ultrastructure remains normal.

questions.text: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other than nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in Fabry's disease. 

Urine analysis in Fabry’s disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.

The following image shows Maltese cross casts:

Note: Maltese cross appearance is also seen in short-range shotgun wounds and babesiosis.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: Basophils are activated by:
questions.solution:
Basophils are activated by IL-5 and IL-3.

Note: IL-5 primarily activates eosinophils.

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
DMT1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte.

Dietary iron is mostly in Fe3+ (ferric state) and must be reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous state) by ferrireductases. Fe2+ iron destined for circulation is transported from the cytoplasm across the basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin 1.

Hephaestin is an iron oxidase that converts Fe2+ to Fe3+

questions.text: Berry aneurysm occurs due to:

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN

questions.solution:
Berry aneurysm occurs due an arterial internal elastic lamina defect.

As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome and the arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base of the neck. The media thins and connective tissue replaces the smooth-muscle cells. The site of rupture is most often the dome. Here the wall thins, and the tear that allows bleeding is usually ≤0.5 mm long. 

Risk of aneurysm rupture is higher if:

  • Aneurysm is >7 mm in diameter
  • Aneurysm at the top of the basilar artery 
  • Aneurysm at the origin of the posterior communicating artery
